section.heading: State Coordination of State Small Business Credit Initiative

para.text: The State’s Department of Business and Economic Development is designated as the entity responsible for the administration of the State Small Business Credit Initiative (SSBCI) in the State.

The Secretary of Business and Economic Development is designated as the official responsible for signing the application and any agreements required to be signed by the State in connection with the application, approval and administration of the SSBCI, including any requests to modify the application and agreements after execution.

section.heading: Governor’s Commission on Maryland Military Monuments

para.text: There is a Governor’s Commission on Maryland Military Monuments.
Membership and Procedures.
The Governor’s Commission consists of up to 21 members appointed by the Governor.
The Chairperson shall be the Maryland Secretary of Veterans Affairs.
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may appoint subcommittees to carry out the work of the commission.
The Governor may remove any member of the Commission for any cause adversely affecting the member’s ability or willingness to perform his or her duties.
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may remove any member of a subcommittee for any cause adversely affecting the member’s ability or willingness to perform his or her duties.
In the event of a vacancy on the Commission, the Governor shall appoint a successor for the remainder of the life of the Commission.
In the event of a vacancy on a subcommittee, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall appoint a successor for the remainder of the life of the subcommittee.

A majority of the Commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any Commission business. In any subcommittee, a majority shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any subcommittee business. The Commission and the subcommittees may adopt such other procedures necessary to ensure the orderly transaction of business.
The members of the Commission and the subcommittees may not receive compensation for their services.
Scope.
The Commission shall undertake an inventory of Maryland military monuments, which shall include the following information:
Name, date of construction, location and means of access, and the original sponsorship of each monument;
Current ownership of each monument and of monument land;
Complete description of each monument including construction materials, condition, theme, and inscriptions, if any; and
Responsibility for maintenance of monument.
The Commission shall make a determination as to the cost of restoration of each monument which is in need of repairs.
The Commission shall assign responsibility for ongoing maintenance of each monument.
The Commission shall procure sufficient funds for the restoration of the monuments.
The Commission shall prepare education and tourism materials for public distribution.

Fundraising. Contributions received by the Commission shall be deposited with the Maryland Military Monument Commission Fund of the [Baltimore Community Foundation, Inc.] MARYLAND VETERANS TRUST FUND within the Department of Veterans Affairs, and disbursed at the direction of the Commission.

section.heading: Maryland Health Quality and Cost Council

para.text: There shall be a Maryland Health Quality and Cost Council (Council).
The Council shall consist of the following members:
The Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene (Secretary); and
Fourteen additional members, to be appointed by the Governor, of which at least twelve shall be representative of the following groups:
Health insurance carriers;
Employers;
Health care providers;
Health care consumers;
Public health experts on the elimination of racial and ethnic disparities; and
Experts in health care quality and cost containment
To the extent practicable, the Council’s composition shall reflect:
The gender, racial, and ethnic diversity of the State; and
The geographic regions of the State.
The Governor shall appoint the chair of the Council. If the Secretary is not the chair of the Council, the Governor shall appoint the Secretary as the co-chair or the vice-chair.
With the exception of the Secretary (who shall be a permanent member of the Council):
The term of a member of the Council shall be three years;
The terms of members appointed by the Governor are staggered, as provided in subsection L;
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A Member:
May not serve more than two consecutive full terms; and
Serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
The Council shall determine the times, places, and frequency of its meetings but shall meet at least four times each year.
A majority of the full authorized membership of the Council is a quorum.
The Council may act upon any matter with the authorization of a majority of the quorum present and voting.
A member of the Council may not receive compensation, but is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations as provided in the State budget.
The Secretary shall designate the staff necessary to provide support for the Council.
The terms of the initial appointed members of the Maryland Health Quality and Cost Council shall expire as follows:
Four members in 2012;
Five members in 2013; and
Five members in 2014.
The Council shall:
Coordinate and facilitate collaboration on health care quality improvement and cost containment initiatives among:
Medical groups, hospitals, and other health care providers;
Health insurance carriers and other health care purchasers;
Health insurance exchanges;
State and local governmental entities;
Health care professional boards;
Health advocacy groups; and
Academic experts in health care.

Develop and implement strategies that will improve the quality and cost-effectiveness of care for individuals with chronic illnesses and at risk of chronic illness, and that are workable and effective for minority communities, recognizing cultural and linguistic differences;

Provide updates on health care quality and cost containment initiatives and priorities to the Governor and General Assembly, the Health Care Reform Coordinating Council, State and local governmental entities, professional boards, industry groups, consumers, and other public and private stakeholders;

Appoint a workgroup to explore and develop health care strategies and initiatives, including financial, performance-based incentives, to reduce and eliminate health disparities, and make recommendations regarding the development and implementation of those strategies. The initiatives should seek to:
Improve quality and reduce costs;
Build on existing efforts to address known disparities; and
Identify best practice disparity programs in Maryland and across the country to determine if and how they should be implemented in Maryland.
Support ongoing efforts to expand the use of health information technology in health care systems;
Seek to leverage opportunities for demonstration and ongoing projects, federal grant funding, and other initiatives to improve quality and contain costs made available by the Affordable Care Act;

Assess options and make recommendations regarding strategies for collecting and disseminating patient-centered outcomes research to develop and promote evidence-based practices among health care providers in the State;
Examine and make recommendations on other issues relating generally to the mission of the Council to improve health care quality and contain health care costs; and
Consider and recommend State public policy strategies for improving health and reducing cost.
The Council shall avoid duplication of existing health care quality improvement and cost containment efforts in the State.
The Council may:
Adopt bylaws, rules, policies, or procedures to conduct business and carry out the purposes of the Council;
Establish workgroups, committees, or task forces;
Designate additional individuals with relevant expertise to serve on the workgroups, committees, or task forces; and
Consult with other units of State and local government to carry out the duties of the Council.

On or before January 1 of each year, the Council shall submit a report to the Governor and the General Assembly, in accordance with Section 2-1246 of the State Government Article, Annotated Code of Maryland, describing:
The activities of the Council during the year, including performance data where applicable; and
Findings and recommendations for improving health care quality, increasing health equity, and reducing health care costs in the State.

section.heading: Governor’s Economic Development and Job Creation Fast Track

para.text: In this Executive Order the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Coordinating Committee” means the committee designated by the Governor’s Chief of Staff under Section D(2) of this Order to assist in the implementation of this Executive Order.
“Priority Funding Area” has the meaning stated in Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Priority Funding Area Exception” means an exception provided for State funding under Sections 5-7B-05(a) or 5-7B-06(a) of the State Finance and Procurement Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.
Established.

There is a Governor’s Economic Development and Job Creation Fast Track (Fast Track) to provide more coordinated, efficient, and expedited review of business and economic development projects with significant State, regional or local impact.

Fast Track is a coordinated review process by State agencies including, but not limited to, the Departments of Business and Economic Development, Transportation, the Environment, Planning, Housing and Community Development, and Natural Resources.
Oversight. The Lieutenant Governor will Chair Fast Track.
Operational Support.
The Governor’s Chief of Staff or the Chief of Staff’s designee shall identify staff to provide operational and other support as needed to implement this Executive Order.

The Governor’s Chief of Staff or the Chief of Staff’s designee shall appoint a project coordinating committee of staff from State agencies or select an existing coordinating committee to assist in the implementation of this Executive Order.
The eligibility criteria for Fast Track are as follows:
The project will produce jobs or economic development that significantly impacts the State, region, county, or municipality;
The project requires the issuance of one or more State permits or approvals; and
The project is located in targeted areas typified by commercial main streets, revitalization and redevelopment areas, and commercial job centers within a Priority Funding Area; or
The project is not located within a Priority Funding Area, but the project meets the criteria for a Priority Funding Area exception.
Application for Expedited Review by Fast Track.

A local government, or project developer may apply to the Fast Track coordinating committee for expedited State review of a project that meets the eligibility criteria by submitting an application form to the committee.
The application form will be located on the Maryland Made Easy website at www.easy.maryland.gov.
In determining whether to recommend an eligible project for review, the Fast Track Coordinating Committee shall consider the following factors:
The significance of the potential economic, job, and business development of the project in relation to the size of the jurisdiction that the project would benefit;
Whether the project is designated as a priority project by a local government;
Whether the project involves infill development or redevelopment;
Whether the project conflicts with an important State policy or goal including whether the project is located in a targeted ecological area or priority agricultural preservation area;
Whether the project furthers an important State policy or goal;
Whether the project is ready to proceed upon issuance of permits and approvals;
Environmental impacts, both positive and negative; and
The capacity of the Fast Track Coordinating Committee to manage projects accepted for review.
After receiving a recommendation on the eligible project from the Fast Track Coordinating Committee, the Chair shall decide whether to accept eligible projects for expedited review.
The Fast Track Coordinating Committee shall notify an applicant if a project is accepted for expedited review.
Fast Track Duties and Activities. The Chair of Fast Track shall:
Determine whether to accept eligible projects for expedited review;
Assign a project coordinator to each accepted project;
Oversee the timeliness of the processing of the requests for approvals and permits and act to eliminate, to the extent possible, delay or inefficiencies; and
Report annually to the Governor on the implementation of this Executive Order including:
The number of projects accepted for expedited review;
The timeliness of the processing of approval and permits of accepted projects; and
Local government participation in Fast Track.
Duties of the Project Coordinator. The Project Coordinator, with the assistance of staff from State agencies, shall:

With a representative of the project, assist in determining the approvals and permits that may be required, the types of information that will be required, and an estimated timeline for applications and processing of accepted projects;
Invite the local jurisdiction or jurisdictions that would be processing approvals and permits at the local level to participate in the review of the project;
Construct a consolidated estimated timeline for discussion with the applicant and the Fast Track coordinating committee; and
Report periodically to the Chair on the progress of application and review of the project.
This Executive Order does not:
Supplant or alter any review or permitting process that is required by law;
Lessen any standard or criteria for permitting or approvals; or
Apply to any federal or local permits or approval processes.

section.heading: Regional Bomb Squad Readiness and Coordination

para.text: The Office of the State Fire Marshal (OSFM) within the Maryland Department of State Police, the Maryland Emergency Management Agency (MEMA), and the Governor’s Office of Homeland Security (GOHS) shall continue to coordinate with the State’s federally accredited local bomb squads in order to provide safe, immediate, and effective responses to bomb threats throughout all regions of the State.
In their coordination with the State’s accredited local bomb squads, the OSFM, MEMA and GOHS shall focus on establishing and promoting:
Mutual aid among Maryland’s accredited bomb squads to ensue effective bomb squad response statewide;
A regional response plan to ensure bomb squad readiness and coordination throughout the State;
Joint training exercises across jurisdictions and disciplines, including law enforcement; and
Mechanisms for sharing and analyzing performance data.
